Iconography

Icons are powerful storytelling tools.

Icons in a font file

We have created our own font file that contains a number of common mono-chromatic icons. This allows the size and color of the icon to be specified using CSS. These icons are referred to as glyphicons.

How to use glyphicons

For performance reasons, all icons require a base class and individual icon class. To use, place the following code just about anywhere. Be sure to leave a space between the icon and text for proper padding.

Don't mix with other components

Icon classes cannot be directly combined with other components. They should not be used along with other classes on the same element. Instead, add a nested <span> and apply the icon classes to the <span>.

Only for use on empty elements

Icon classes should only be used on elements that contain no text content and have no child elements.

<span class="glyphicon glyphicon-search"></span>

Examples

Use them at different sizes.

14px 16px (Default) 20px 30px 
<span class="glyphicon glyphicon-xs glyphicon-lightbulb"></span>
<span class="glyphicon glyphicon-sm glyphicon-lightbulb"></span>
<span class="glyphicon glyphicon-md glyphicon-lightbulb"></span>
<span class="glyphicon glyphicon-lg glyphicon-lightbulb"></span>

Use them in buttons, button groups for a toolbar, navigation, or prepended form inputs.

<button type="button" class="btn btn-default btn-lg">
	<span class="glyphicon glyphicon-save"></span> Save
</button>

Use them in a stacked view.

<span class="x1-icon-stack-sm">
	<i class="glyphicon glyphicon-star text-info"></i>
	<i class="glyphicon glyphicon-star-empty"></i>
</span>
<span class="x1-icon-stack-md">
	<i class="glyphicon glyphicon-circle text-success"></i>
	<i class="glyphicon glyphicon-circle-empty"></i>
</span>
<span class="x1-icon-stack-lg">
	<i class="glyphicon glyphicon-diamond text-danger"></i>
	<i class="glyphicon glyphicon-diamond-empty"></i>
</span>

Icons are powerful storytelling tools. As you use the icons, imagine how the user experiences of your product could be told by the character of the icons alone. As a best practice in accessibility, all non-textual informational elements should have text-based equivalents

An icon is typically an on-screen, small graphical image that uses metaphor to represent actions or objects that a user can select or manipulate within a user interface. They provide a quick way to execute commands, open documents, and run programs. Icons are also very useful when searching for an object. Within the context of a product user interface, a graphical element is an icon (static or interactive) or an accent graphic (static only).

Peretz uses the IBM Design Language icon style. Thus, the icons are flat and mono- or dichromatic.

For IBM Commerce, we’ve designed a set of IBM Commerce-specific icons that addresses the needs of our products while keeping the IBM Design Language styling. For example, for our analytics offerings, we’ve designed icons that use the appropriate metaphors for analytics.

We’ll also be translating the over 200+ icons into glyphs – which work in all browsers and on all platforms – so that our development teams can easily incorporate them.

Glyphs

Glyphs are visual symbols set at 24 x 24 pixels, the smallest recommended size for touch interfaces. They are distinguished by their easily identifiable solid shape and knocked out details. Use glyphs when formatting a tool bar or on narrow sub-navigation bar. Create glyphs that maintain consistency with their icon counterparts, based on the icon building principles.

Icons

Icons are visual symbols set at 16 x 16, 20 x 20 and 30 x 30 pixels. They address the majority of use cases in our software out of the three types (glyphs, icons, and tooling icons).They are comprised of three building blocks: simple geometry, precise outlines and balancing solids. Icons accommodate for limited space, but are sized for interactive, touch-friendly experiences. They can indicate change, provide visual cues for the eye and increase recognition. Take extra care to align the icon to a grid and select a line weight from the size up or down as reference. The line weight from 16 x 16 pixels is carried over to 30 x 30 pixels:

  • 16px x 16px - 1 pixel outline; 6px spacing beside text
  • 20px x 20px - 1 pixel outline; 8px spacing beside text
  • 30px x 30px - 2 pixel outline; 10px spacing beside text

Alignment: Center align/Middle align.

Tooling icons

Tooling icons are visual symbols set at 40 x 40 pixels.

Alignment: Center align/Middle align.

Accessibility

Modern versions of assisting technologies will announce CSS generated content, as well as specific Unicode characters. To avoid unintended and confusing output in screen readers (particularly when icons are used purely for decoration), we hide them with the aria-hidden="true" attribute.

Examples

If you're using an icon to convey meaning (rather than only as a decorative element), ensure that this meaning is also conveyed by applying a sr-only class.

Error: Enter a valid email address 

<div class="alert alert-danger" role="alert">
                <span class="glyphicon glyphicon-error-circle" aria-hidden="true"></span>
                <span class="sr-only">Error:</span>
                Enter a valid email address
                </div>

If you're creating controls with no other text (such as a <button> that only contains an icon), you should always provide alternative content to identify the purpose of the control. In this case, you could add an aria-label attribute on the control itself.

<button type="button" class="btn btn-default" aria-label="Save As">
                <span class="glyphicon glyphicon-md glyphicon-save-as" aria-hidden="true"></span>
                </button>
